. The Antrim coast is one of the most beautiful parts of Northern Ireland, with the Antrim Coast Road taking in some of the best scenery in the country.
is one of the most striking landscapes on Earth and is a

is where mostly farmers go to party, with most heading for a better night out in Belfast. It is one of Ireland's most fascinating counties. It is also home of the Ulster Grand Prix, set in the tiny village of Dundrod and is the world's fastest motorcycle racing circuit.

Antrim the county town is worth a visit with many historical locations and for the bargain hunters a large outlet centre and huge Saturday morning bootsale at dunsilly
is situated near the town of
, and is convenient for exploring the region. Ferries from Scotland land at

operates the public transport system in Antrim.
It has both Rail and Bus services
Standard Northern Irish fare, but if you're lucky enough to catch the
(held on the last Monday and Tuesday of August), be sure to try
, a rock hard yellow sweet that is eaten with the aid of a hammer. Make sure your dental insurance is up to date first.

Distillery, of course. You can take distillery tours, and you'll likely be more merry going out than when you went in.  It's worth noting that at the end of each tour four people from the tour group (two women and two men) are asked to volunteer for a special whiskey tasting, where participants get to try

different types of whiskey.

US visitors who are unaccustomed to driving on the left are well advised to shun the whiskey tasting.  Buy some to take back to your hotel.
Stay sensible, don't wander around urban areas at night or make political statements in strange company, and you'll be just fine.
